ygData.subject: Re: PLEASE Help, I keep getting booted a
ygData.msgSnippet: Alright... 1st... define booted. 1) Booted from Server on EQ 2) Booted from ISP 3) Booted from EQ Entirely If it s Server, or EQ... you
ygData.messageBody:
Alright... 1st... define booted.<br><br>1) Booted
from Server on EQ<br>2) Booted from ISP<br>3) Booted
from EQ Entirely<br><br>If it's Server, or EQ... you
might want to uninstall/reinstall EQ.<br><br>HOWEVER,
AOL 6.0 is notorious in most tech circles for being
really hard to hack out. I've been told that sometimes--
if you get a tech that knows who's good at AOL-- you
can get them to registry hack for you. But the
problem is, trusting AOL for a registry
hack?<br><br>Also, did you delete AOL or did you uninstall AOL? It
does make a difference although AOL 6.0 almost makes
it a moot point-- as many registry entries as its
uninstall leaves behind.<br><br>It is likely AOL
conflicting with Bellsouth if you're getting connection
boots. Also it could be possible Bellsouth has been set
to disconnect after 10 or 15 mins if you don't click
"yes stay connected". There's the possibility that
that's coming up in the background and you can't see it
b/c of course EQ takes up everything and then you get
disconnected-- which of course punts you from EQ.<br><br>Hope
some of this helps and you don't end up having to
Format, Reinstall. Course if you have WinME, just do a
system restore to before you had issues. ME has its
flaws but system restore rocks. ME allocates 400MBs to
System Restore and each restore table takes 3+kb AND you
can make up to 9 user restore points on any given day
(for a total of 10 in one day). Course it takes over
HDD's and puts itself in the boot sector, has a super
hidden io.sys that can't be deleted or even found in DOS
(try to derash it from a boot disk- gluck finding it--
can in versions up to Win2k though). It's hard to
crash completely though. If you know what you're doing,
you can deletely Hkey_Local registries and still fix
it without a format. Still, the fact that an
fdisk/format doesn't completely remove it from an HDD is a
bummer. (sorry. Have had to deal with the ups and downs
of ME for a while. Sigh/grin)<br><br>Anyway, I'm
rambling. Gluck<br>shooman out
